Compiled by Shi Huijiao, a monk from Jiaxiang Temple in Kuaiji, Liang Dynasty

Zhu Shixing, originally from Central India, was well-versed in both the exoteric and esoteric teachings, and often traveled to spread the Dharma.
In the past, he once went to a small country under the rule of India to lecture on the Golden Light SÅ«tra. At that time, a neighboring country invaded the border. Shixing thought to himself:
The sÅ«tra says:
'If one can expound this sÅ«tra,
The earth spirits will protect them.
Causing their dwelling place to be peaceful and joyful.'
Now that the enemy is about to attack, will this bring any benefit?
He then vowed to forget himself and personally went to mediate, and the two countries became friendly. Because of this, he became famous.
In the Yongping period of the Han dynasty, Emperor Ming had a dream one night of a golden man flying in the air. He then gathered his ministers to interpret the dream.
The scholar Fu Yi respectfully replied:
I have heard that in the Western Regions there is a deity called 'Buddha.'
Your Majesty's dream must be about him.
The Emperor agreed and sent Langzhong Cai Yin and Qin Jing, a disciple of the Doctor,
to India to search for the Buddha's teachings.
Yin and the others met with Ma Teng there and persuaded him to return to China.

Teng vowed to spread the teachings and did not mind the hardships, braving the shifting sands to reach Luoyang. Emperor Ming welcomed him with great honor and built a monastery outside the western city gate for him to stay in. This was the beginning of monks in China.
However, when the great Dharma was first transmitted, there were no believers, so he kept his profound understanding to himself and did not proclaim it.
Later, he died in Luoyang.
There is a record saying:
Teng translated the Sutra in Forty-two Sections in one fascicle.
It was first sealed in the fourteenth chamber of the stone chamber in the Lantai.
The place where he stayed is now the White Horse Temple outside Yongmen in the west of Luoyang city.
The legend says:
Once the king of a foreign country destroyed many temples, but the Zhao Temple was not yet destroyed.
At night, a white horse circled the pagoda and neighed sadly. The king was informed and immediately stopped the destruction of the temples.
Therefore, the Zhao Temple was renamed White Horse.
Thus, many temples took this as an example when naming themselves.
Zhu Falan, also from Central India, claimed to have memorized tens of thousands of chapters of sutras and treatises, and was a teacher of Indian scholars.
When Cai Yin arrived in that country, Falan and Moteng agreed to travel and spread the Dharma, so they followed each other to China.
As the scholars in India wanted to keep them, Falan left in secret and arrived in China.
After arriving in Luoyang, he stayed with Moteng. In a short time, he became fluent in Chinese.

An Shigao obtained the sutras in the Western Regions and immediately translated five parts: the Ten Grounds Sutra, Sutra on Cutting Off Bonds, Buddha's Past Lives, Dharma Ocean Treasury, Buddha's Past Practices, and the Sutra in Forty-two Sections.

When the capital was moved due to chaos, four parts were lost and not transmitted to the south of the Yangtze River. Only the Sutra in Forty-two Sections is still extant, with about two thousand words.
Among the sutras preserved in China, this is the beginning.
An Shigao also obtained a painted standing image of Shakyamuni from the Western Regions, which was the fourth work of the sandalwood image master of King Udayana.
When it arrived in Luoyang, Emperor Ming ordered painters to copy it and place it in the Qingliang Terrace and Xianjie Hill. The old image no longer exists.
Moreover, in the past, Emperor Wu of the Han Dynasty dug to the bottom of Kunming Pool and found black ash. He asked Dongfang Shuo about it, who said:
I do not know.
You can ask the people from the Western Regions.
Later, when Dharmaraká¹£a arrived, the people pursued him and asked about it. Dharmaraká¹£a said:
The end of the world, the burning of the kalpa fire, this ash is it.
The words of the previous person were verified, and there were many believers.
Dharmaraká¹£a later died in Luoyang at over sixty years old.
An Qing, whose courtesy name was Shigao, was the crown prince of the legitimate queen of the king of Arsakes.

From a young age, he was known for his filial conduct, and moreover, he was intelligent and diligent in his studies. He mastered the scriptures of foreign countries, the seven luminaries, the five elements, medical methods, and various techniques, up to the sounds of birds and beasts, without exception.
Once, while walking, he suddenly said to his companion:
The swallows say there should be someone bringing food.
Soon, there indeed was someone who brought it.
The crowd marveled at him, and thus his reputation for outstanding talent spread throughout the Western Regions early on.

Although Gao was a layman, he strictly observed the precepts. When the king passed away, he succeeded to the throne. He deeply contemplated suffering and emptiness, and became disgusted with his physical body. After the mourning period was over, he abdicated the throne to his uncle and left home to practice the Way.
He extensively studied the Buddhist canon and was especially proficient in Abhidharma studies. He recited the meditation scriptures and roughly mastered their subtleties.
He then traveled around to spread the Dharma and visited various countries. In the beginning of the Han Huan era, he arrived in China for the first time.

He was talented and quick-witted, and could understand things after hearing them once. Before long after arriving, he became fluent in Chinese.ğŸ”½He then translated various scriptures, changing them from the language of the Western Regions to Chinese. He translated the Anban Shouyi Jing, the Yin Chiru Jing, the Small and Large Shiermen Jing, and the Bailiu Jing.

Originally, the Indian Tripiá¹­aka master AÅ›vaghoá¹£a compiled the essentials of the sÅ«tras into twenty-seven chapters. Gao then analyzed and translated the seven chapters compiled by AÅ›vaghoá¹£a into Chinese, which is the Daodi Jing.
The sutras and treatises he translated earlier and later totaled thirty-nine works.
The principles are clearly analyzed, and the words are correct. They are concise but not ornate, simple but not rustic. All who read them find them engaging and never tire of them.
Gao thoroughly understood the principles and exhausted the nature of things. He himself knew his karmic causes and effects, and had many spiritual traces that the world could not fathom.

At first, Gao claimed that in his previous life he had already left the household life. There was a classmate who was very angry. When begging for alms, if the donors did not meet his expectations, he would always be resentful.
Gao repeatedly admonished him, but he never reformed.
In this way, for more than twenty years, he took leave of his classmate, saying:

I will go to Guangzhou to end the karmic retribution from my past lives. You are proficient in the sutras and diligent, not inferior to me, but you are very angry. After your death, you will receive an evil form. If I attain the Way, I will surely save you.
Then he went to Guangzhou.
He encountered a great disturbance by bandits and thieves. On the road, he met a young man who drew his sword with his bare hands and said:
I have truly found you.
Gao laughed and said:
I owe you from my past life, so I came from afar to repay you.
Your anger is the intention from your previous life.
He then extended his neck to receive the sword, his expression showing no fear, and the bandit then killed him.
The onlookers filled the streets, none of them were not amazed by his strangeness.
His consciousness then returned to be the crown prince of the King of Arsakes, which is now the body of Shi Gao.

Gao traveled and taught in China, and after finishing spreading the sutras, he encountered the turmoil at the end of the Lingdi era in Guanzhong and Luoyang, so he shook his staff to the south of the Yangtze River, saying:
I should pass Mount Lu to save my classmates from the past.

He arrived at the temple of the Lake of the Cauldron Pavilion. This temple had long been spiritually powerful. Merchants and travelers prayed to it, and the wind would then blow up and down, each without any delay.
Once someone asked for divine bamboo, but before permission was granted, they took it themselves. The boat immediately capsized, and the bamboo returned to its original place.
From then on, boat people respected and feared it, and no one dared to offend it.
Gao was traveling with over thirty other boats, offering sacrifices and seeking blessings. The deity then descended and said:
There is a Å›ramaá¹‡a on the boat, you may call him up.
The guests were all shocked and invited Gao to enter the temple.
The deity told Gao:

In the past, in a foreign country, we both left home to study the Way. I liked to practice giving, but I had a short temper. Now I am the deity of the Quting Temple, and the surrounding thousand li are under my jurisdiction.
Because of my giving, I have many precious and wonderful things. Because of my anger, I have fallen into this divine retribution.
Now seeing my fellow student, I am both sad and happy.
My life is about to end, and my ugly form is huge. If I abandon my life here, it will pollute the rivers and lakes. I should cross to the marshes west of the mountains.

After my body perishes, I fear falling into hell. I have a thousand bolts of silk and various treasures. You can use them to build a monastery and erect a stupa, so that I may be reborn in a good place.
Gao said:
I came here to save you. Why don't you show your form?
The spirit said:
My form is extremely ugly and strange. Many people will surely be afraid.
Gao said:
Just show yourself. Many people will not be surprised.

The spirit emerged from behind the bed, and it was a huge python. They did not know how long its tail was, but it reached Gao's knees. Gao spoke to it in Sanskrit for several times, and chanted sutras for several rounds. The python wept tears like rain, and in an instant, it disappeared again.

Gao then took the silk and other things, took his leave, and left. The boat crew raised the sails. The python again emerged from the mountain, gazed at them, and then the people waved their hands. Only then did it disappear.
In a short while, they arrived at Yuzhang. Gao immediately used the temple offerings to build Dongsi Monastery. After Gao left, the spirit passed away.
In the evening, a young man boarded the boat, knelt before Gao, received his mantra and blessings, and suddenly disappeared. Gao said to the boatmen:
The young man just now was the deity of the Quting Temple. He has escaped his evil form.
Thus, the temple deity ceased and there were no more miraculous occurrences.
Later, people saw a dead python in the marshes of the western mountains, several li long from head to tail, which is now Shecun Village in Xunyang County.

Gao later went to Guangzhou again to find the young man from his past life who had harmed him. At that time, the young man was still alive. Gao went to his house and told him about repaying their karmic debts and explained their past connections. They happily faced each other and said:
I still have remaining karmic retributions. I will now go to Kuaiji to finish repaying them.

The guest from Guangzhou realized that Gao was extraordinary and suddenly understood. He regretted his past mistakes and generously provided support. He followed Gao east and eventually reached Kuaiji.
He then entered the market, but just as he arrived, there was a disturbance in the market. Someone who was fighting mistakenly hit Gao Tou, who died instantly.

The Guangzhou guest frequently experienced the two retributions, and thus diligently practiced Buddhism, fully explaining the circumstances. Those who heard far and near were all saddened, clearly understanding the existence of the three periods of past, present, and future.
Since Gao was of royal blood, the guests from the Western Regions all called him An Hou, which is still his title to this day.
The country of India calls its writing Heavenly Writing and its language Heavenly Language. The sounds and meanings are strange and difficult, quite different from Chinese.
In the past and present, many translations have been erroneous and confused. Only what was produced by Gao is the foremost among the many translations.
An Gong thought:
If it were as if personally receiving [the teachings], it would be no different from seeing the Sage. The illustrious virtues of the generations praised and contemplated it.

I have searched through various records, and the biographies of Gao Gong have different versions. I think it is due to the concealment and revelation of his traces, responding to the many aspects that should be abandoned, or because the transmitters made mistakes, causing discrepancies. I have listed all the different versions, hoping that they can be discussed.
According to Shi Daoyan's Sutra Catalog:
An Shigao translated more than thirty sutras in the more than twenty years from the second year of Jianhe of Emperor Huan of Han to the Jianning period of Emperor Ling.
Another Separate Biography says:
At the end of the Taikang period of the Jin dynasty, a Daoist monk named An Shigao came to Sangyuan and finished translating the sutras. He sealed a box in the temple, saying:
'It can be opened in four years.'
At the end of the Wu dynasty, he went to Yangzhou and had a man sell a box of goods to buy a slave named Fushan, saying, 'He is my good friend.'
He then took the slave to Yuzhang and crossed the Fanting Temple, establishing a temple for the temple deity. When it was completed, Fushan stabbed Anhou in the side with a knife and died.
The people of Sangyuan then opened the sealed box, and the financial arrangements were written in characters, saying:
The one who respects my way is the layman Chen Hui, and the one who transmits the Chan scriptures is the monk Seng Hui.
This was exactly the fourth year.
Also, Yu Zhongyong's Record of Jingzhou says:
In the early years of the Jin dynasty, there was a monk named An Shigao who crossed the Fanting Temple and obtained wealth. He established the White Horse Temple in the southeast corner of Jingcheng.
The Record of Manifestations by the King of Linchuan in the Song dynasty says:
The python died at the end of the Wu dynasty.
Tan Zong's Record of Stupas and Temples says:
Waguan Temple in Danyang was established by Monk Huili during the reign of Emperor Ai of the Jin dynasty. Later, Monk An Shigao repaired it with the remaining funds from the Fanting Temple.
However, Dharma Master Dao'an has collated the various scriptures and recorded the translations, which must not be mistaken.

From the second year of Jianhe in the Han dynasty to the end of the Taikang era in the Jin dynasty, a total of more than 140 years have passed. If Elder Gao lived a long life, it may be so, but the matter is not so. Why is it so?
According to the preface to the Anban Shouyi Jing annotated by Kang Senghui:
This sutra was translated by Zhi Qian a long time ago, but it has been lost for a long time.

Later, Han Lin of Nanyang, Wen Ye of Yingchuan, and Chen Hui of Kuaiji, these three virtuous ones, who had a deep faith in the Way, jointly requested to receive [the teaching]. Chen Hui expounded the meaning, and I assisted in making judgments.
It is said that Seng Hui died in the first year of Taikang in the Jin dynasty, and yet it is said:
This sutra was translated a long time ago, but it has been lost for a long time.
Moreover, the inscription on the sealed case by Zhi Qian says:
The one who respects my Way is the layman Chen Hui;
The monk Seng Hui is the one who transmitted the Chan scriptures.
However, the Anban Sutra mainly discusses Chan practices, so the record of sealing the box is certainly not a false creation.
Since it says that the two people will transmit the Way, how can it be allowed that they shared the same era?
Moreover, the separate biography itself says:
The monk Seng Hui is the one who transmitted the Chan scriptures.
Since Seng Hui had already died in the beginning of the Taikang era, how could there be a Daoist monk named An Hou at the end of the Taikang era?

The statements at the beginning and end contradict each other. It is appropriate that one of the texts mistakenly points to the beginning of the Jin dynasty, and then later authors either say it was the Taikang era or the end of the Wu dynasty, all rushing to agree without any basis for comparison.
Since the claim of the beginning of the Jin dynasty is already difficult to accept, the record by Tan Zong says:
During the reign of Emperor Ai of the Jin dynasty, Shi Hu was again in charge of the temple.
His mistaken statements are even more absurd.

4. Zhi Lou Jia Chan, also known as Zhi Chan, was originally from Yuezhi. His conduct was pure and profound, and his nature was open and sharp. He upheld the precepts with utmost sincerity and diligence.
He recited many sutras, and his intention was to spread the Dharma.

During the time of Emperor Ling of the Han Dynasty, he traveled to Luoyang. During the Guanghe and Zhongping periods, he translated Sanskrit texts and produced three sutras: the Prajnaparamita Sutra, the Pratyutpanna Sutra, and the Shoulengyan Sutra.
There were also more than ten sutras such as the Ajatashatru Sutra and the RatnakÅ«á¹­a Sutra, but they were not recorded for a long time.
Master An examined the ancient and modern versions and carefully studied the literary style, saying:

It seems to be the works of Chan. All these sutras accurately capture the original meaning and do not add any embellishments. He can truly be called a propagator of the essential teachings and a disseminator of the Dharma.
Later, his whereabouts are unknown.

At that time, there was a monk from India named Zhu Foshuo, who also brought the Sutra of the Way of Practice to Luoyang during the time of Emperor Ling of Han and translated it from Sanskrit into Chinese.
Although the translators were sometimes hindered and there were misunderstandings, they discarded the text and focused on the substance, deeply capturing the meaning of the sutra.

Foshuo also translated the Pratyutpanna SamÄdhi Sutra in Luoyang in the second year of Guanghe. Zhi Qian transmitted the words, and Meng Fu and Zhang Lian of Luoyang in Henan took down the translation.
At that time, there was also an upÄsaka named An Xuan, a man from Arsakes. He was honest and sincere, and had a deep understanding of principles.
He recited many sutras and was well-versed in various teachings.ğŸ”½He also traveled to Luoyang at the end of the reign of Emperor Ling of Han.
He was given the title of Qi Duwei for his merits.
He was by nature aloof and gentle, and always considered spreading the Dharma his responsibility.
He gradually understood Chinese and was determined to spread the scriptures. He often discussed the principles of the Way with monks, and was known as Duwei in the world.

Xuan together with the Å›ramaá¹‡a Yan Futiao translated the Sutra of the Dharma Mirror. Xuan orally translated the Sanskrit text, and Futiao took it down in writing. The meaning and pronunciation were correct, and they fully grasped the subtle purport of the sutra. The beauty of the skilled craftsman was described in later generations.

Futiao was originally from Linhuai. At an early age he was insightful and fond of learning. The world praised him, An Hou, and Duwei as the three. They were called difficult to succeed in translation.
Futiao also composed the Ten Wisdoms, which are also transmitted in the world.
An Gong praised Futiao's sutra translation as concise yet not verbose, and fully skillful.

There were also the Å›ramaá¹‡as Zhi Yao, Kang Ju, Kang Mengxiang, and others. They all had the reputation of wisdom learning during the reigns of Emperor Ling and Emperor Xian of the Han dynasty, and were renowned in the capital city of Luoyang.
Yao translated the Sutra of Perfect Concentration and the Sutra of the Lesser Past Events, etc.;
Ju translated the Sutra on Inquiring about the Affairs of Hell. They both spoke straightforwardly and did not add embellishments to the meaning.
Meng Xiang translated the Middle-arising and the Practice-arising.
Previously, the Å›ramaá¹‡a Tan Guo obtained the Sanskrit text in the country of Kapilavastu. Meng Xiang and Zhu Dali translated it into Chinese. Master An said:
What Meng Xiang has produced is clear and flowing, sufficient to convey the profound meaning.
DharmatrÄta DharmatrÄta, which means Dharma Time, was originally from Central India.

His family was very wealthy and always practiced pure giving.ğŸ”½DharmatrÄta was talented and intelligent from a young age, with an appearance surpassing others. He read a book once and understood all the text and meaning.
He was well-versed in the Four Vedas, and in astronomy, meteorology, and divination, he was all-encompassing. He said that all the literature and principles in the world were in his mind and belly.

At the age of twenty-five, he entered a monastery and happened to see the *Abhidharma-há¹›daya-Å›Ästra. He picked it up to read it, but was confused and did not understand. He carefully reviewed it again, but became even more perplexed. He then sighed and said:
I have been studying for many years, but my ambitions have been in the classics. I have been cutting through the scriptures, not thinking about the meaning again, and not reviewing the text.
Now, seeing the Buddhist scriptures, they suddenly go beyond my thoughts. They must have a profound principle and a special essence.

Thereupon, he took the scroll into his room and asked a monk to briefly explain it for him. He then deeply understood causality and wonderfully penetrated the three periods of time. He finally knew that the Buddhist teachings are vast and expansive, and the secular books cannot compare.
He then abandoned worldly glory, left home, and diligently practiced asceticism, reciting the scriptures of the Mahayana and Hinayana, as well as the various Vinayas.
He always valued traveling and teaching, and did not enjoy staying in one place. During the Jiaping era of the Wei dynasty, he came to Luoyang.

At that time, although Buddhism existed in the Wei territory, the way of the Dharma had degenerated. There were also many monks who had not received the precepts of refuge, just with a shaved head and different customs.
Even if they held purification ceremonies, they were conducted like worshipping the gods. When KÄlayaÅ›as arrived, he greatly promoted the Buddha Dharma.

At that time, the monks together requested KÄlayaÅ›as to translate the Vinaya scriptures. KÄlayaÅ›as thought that the Vinaya texts were complicated and lengthy, and that if Buddhism had not yet flourished, they would not be accepted.
He then translated the SÅ«tra on the Essence of the PrÄtimoká¹£a of the MahÄsÄá¹ƒghika School.
It was enough to cover the morning and evening.
He further requested the Indian monks to establish the karma method for receiving the precepts. The precepts and Vinaya of China began from this.
Later, it is unknown where KÄlayaÅ›as passed away.
At that time, there was also the foreign Å›ramaá¹‡a Kang Sengkai, who also came to Luoyang at the end of the Jiping era.
He translated and produced four sÅ«tras, including the Ugraparipá¹›cchÄ-sÅ«tra.
There was also a monk named Tandi from Parthia who was also proficient in Vinaya studies. During the Zhengyuan period of Wei, he came to Luoyang and translated the Karma of Dharmagupta.
There was also a monk named Bo Yan, whose origins are unknown.
He was also talented and wise with deep understanding. During the Gandeng period of Wei, he translated six sutras including the Sutra of Immeasurable Pure and Equal Enlightenment.
Later, his whereabouts are unknown.
Kang Senghui, Kang Senghui, whose ancestors were from Kangju, lived in India for generations. His father moved to Jiaozhi due to trade.
When Senghui was over ten years old, both his parents passed away. After completing the mourning period, he became a monk.
He was very diligent in his practice and had a magnanimous and perceptive character. He was devoted to learning.
He had a clear understanding of the Tripiá¹­aka and was well-versed in the Six Classics, astronomy, and geography. He was skilled in political strategy and wrote some literary works.
At that time, Sun Quan had already controlled the Jiangzuo region, but Buddhism had not yet been practiced there.
There was a lay Buddhist named Zhi Qian, whose courtesy name was Gongming, also known as Yue, who was originally from Yuezhi.
In the time of Emperor Huan and Emperor Ling of the Han dynasty, Zhi Chen translated many scriptures.
There was Zhi Liang, whose courtesy name was Jiming, who studied under Chen. Qian further studied under Liang.
He extensively read the scriptures and thoroughly understood them. He was proficient in various worldly skills.
He studied different scripts and understood the languages of the six kingdoms.
People said of him:
Zhi Lang has yellow eyes, although his body is small, he is a treasure of wisdom.

At the end of the reign of Emperor Xian of the Han, he fled to Wu due to the chaos. Sun Quan heard of his talent and wisdom, summoned him, and was delighted. He appointed him as a professor to assist the crown prince. Together with Wei Yao and others, he fully provided guidance and assistance. However, since he was born in a foreign land, the Wu History did not record him.

Qian thought that although the great teaching had been transmitted, many scriptures were still in Sanskrit and had not been fully translated. Since he was already proficient in the language, he collected various versions and translated them into Chinese.

From the first year of the Huangwu era of Wu to the Jianxing era, he produced forty-nine sutras including the Vimalakirti Sutra, the Mahaparinirvana Sutra, the Dharmapada, and the Sutra of the Original Life of the Buddha. He skillfully grasped the holy meaning and the words were elegant.

He also composed three chapters of Bodhi Connected Verses and Brahma Songs based on the Sutra of Immeasurable Life and the Sutra of the Middle Original Life, as well as annotations to the Sutra of Understanding the Origin of Life and Death, which are all circulated in the world.

At that time, the great Dharma had just been introduced to the Wu region, and the wind of transformation was not yet complete. Seng Hui wanted to make the Way flourish in Jiang Zuo and establish temples, so he traveled east with his staff. In the tenth year of the Red Bird era of Wu, he first arrived in Jianye, built thatched huts, set up images, and practiced the Way.
At that time, the Wu kingdom, having seen monks for the first time, had not yet understood their Way, and suspected them to be strange and deceptive.
The officials reported:
There are Hu people entering the country, claiming to be monks. Their appearance and attire are unusual. Their affairs should be investigated.
Sun Quan said:
In the past, Emperor Ming of the Han dreamed of a divine being called the Buddha. Could it be that they are the remaining influence of that?
He then summoned Hui and questioned him, asking for any spiritual evidence.
Hui said:
Since the Tathagata's passing, it has been over a thousand years. His remaining bones and relics emit spiritual radiance in all directions. In the past, King Asoka built 84,000 stupas.
The reason for the establishment of stupas and temples is to manifest the remaining teachings.
Sun Quan thought it was boastful and said to Hui:
If you can obtain the relics, I will build a stupa for you. If it is false, the country has a fixed punishment.
Hui requested seven days.
He said to his followers:
The rise and fall of the Dharma depends on this one attempt. If we are not sincere now, what will we do later?
They then purified the quiet room together, placed a copper vase on an altar, burned incense, and made requests.
After the seven-day period ended, there was a complete silence, without any response. They requested to extend it by another two seven-day periods, but it was the same.
Sun Quan said this was truly deceptive and was about to punish them. Hui again requested three seven-day periods, and Sun Quan specially allowed it. Hui said to his Dharma followers:
Confucius said:
'After King Wen passed away, is the culture not here?'
If the Dharma is truly efficacious, the relics will descend. If we have no karmic affinity, what need is there for royal edicts? We shall take an oath to die here.
After three weeks, still nothing was seen, and everyone was shaken with fear.
When the fifth watch approached, they suddenly heard a loud sound from the vase. Hui went to see for himself and indeed found the relics.
The next morning, they presented them to Sun Quan, and the entire court gathered to observe. Five-colored lights and flames illuminated the top of the vase.
Quan personally held the vase and poured the contents onto a copper plate. Where the relics struck, the plate shattered.
Quan was greatly startled and said:
This is an extremely rare auspicious sign!
Hui continued, saying:
The majestic spiritual power of the relics is not just limited to emitting light. They cannot be burned by the fires at the end of the eon, nor can they be crushed by a vajra hammer.
Quan ordered a test, and Hui made another vow, saying:
The Dharma cloud has been spread, and the people look up to your grace. I wish you would further show your spiritual traces to further demonstrate your majestic spirit.
He then placed the relic on an iron anvil and had a strong man strike it. The anvil and hammer were both dented, but the relic was unharmed.
Sun Quan greatly admired and respected this, and immediately built a stupa. Since it was the first Buddhist temple, it was called Jianchu Temple, and the area was named Buddhaloka Lane.
Thus, the great Dharma in Jiangzuo was finally established.
When Sun Hao came to power, his laws were harsh and cruel. He abolished licentious sacrifices and even Buddhist temples, wanting to destroy them all.
Hao said:
Why was this established? If its teachings are true and in accord with the scriptures, then I will uphold its path.
If it is without substance, then I will burn it all.
The ministers all said:
The power of the Buddha is unlike that of other gods.
Kang Senghui's auspicious response, the great emperor's establishment of the temple, if now lightly defiled, I fear it will lead to regret.

Hao sent Zhang Yu to the temple to question Senghui. Zhang Yu had a natural talent for debate and asked difficult questions from all angles. Senghui responded with eloquence and his arguments were sharp. From dawn to dusk, Zhang Yu was unable to defeat him.
After Zhang Yu left, Senghui saw him off at the gate. At that time, there were licentious sacrifices nearby. Zhang Yu said:
Since the profound teachings have been accepted, why do these people still not change even though they are close by?
Senghui said:
Thunder and lightning can shatter mountains, but the deaf do not hear them. It is not because the sound is subtle.
If it is in accord with principle, then it will respond from thousands of miles away. If it is blocked, then the liver and gall will be as distant as Chu and Yue.
Zhang Yu returned and sighed, Senghui's talent and wisdom are not something I can fathom. I wish the emperor would investigate this.
Hao gathered the court officials and welcomed Senghui with a horse carriage.
When Senghui took his seat, Hao asked:
What are the good and evil retributions that the Buddha's teachings clarify?
Hui replied:
When a wise ruler instructs the world with filial piety and kindness, then red-crested birds fly and old people are seen.
When benevolent virtue nurtures beings, then sweet springs gush forth and auspicious seedlings appear.
Since goodness has auspicious signs, evil is also like this.
Therefore, if one does evil in secret, ghosts can punish it; if one does evil in the open, people can punish it.

The Book of Changes says, 'Accumulating goodness brings blessings,' and the Book of Poetry praises, 'Seeking blessings is not in vain.' Although these are the principles of Confucian classics, they are also the clear teachings of Buddhism.
Hao said:
If that is so, then since the Duke of Zhou and Confucius have already clarified this, what is the use of Buddhism?
Hui said:
